nexttext:
where the derivative is taken with respect to the kinetic energy of the photoelectron. In the original EWS model, developed for particle scattered by a Coulomb-like potential, the phase-shift is between the incoming and outcoming particles, where $\tau_{\textsc{ews}}$ is interpreted as a ``sticking'' time in the interaction potential region. In the photoemission context, the excited photoelectron is considered to be ``half-scattered'' by its original atomic environment \cite{Pazourek:2013}, thus the corresponding $\tau_{\textsc{ews}}$ represents the interaction of the excited electron with the surrounding potential, i.e. the time-delay of the photoemission in the one-step model, as illustrated in Fig.~\ref{fig:picture}(a). 
\begin{figure} [ht]
	\centering
		\includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{fig1.pdf}
	\caption{(a) Two phase-shifted transitions interfere in the photoemission process to build up the photoelectron wavefunction; (b) experimental setup with relevant planes and axis indicated.}
	\label{fig:picture}
\end{figure}
The phase-shift is also connected to other physical quantities, such as the quasi-particle self-energy \cite{Fishbane:1969}, and thus provides relevant information for the study of collective excitations and correlations. The development of a ``EWS-phase-resolved'' spectroscopy would bring important contributions to the study of strongly-correlated electron systems, in addition to a deeper understanding of the basic physical process of photoemission itself.
We propose to access the phase information through the measurement of the \emph{spin polarization} of photoelectrons emitted from a spin-degenerate initial state \cite{Heinzmann:2012}.
The model proposed here permits us to exploit the capabilities of spin- and angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (SARPES) on non-magnetic systems \cite{Dil:2009R} in order to extract the photoelectron interaction time in a solid via the phase-shift by measuring the spin of photoelectrons maintaining full energy and angular resolution. Using the Cu(111) \textit{sp}-bulk band as a model system we will present the first experimental determination of an inferior limit for the time-delay via the spin polarization.\\


In photoionization from atoms two different transitions can interfere and the photoelectrons show a spin polarization as a function of the angle between the electric field of the incident light and the photoelectron momentum, as derived considering the process as a ``half-scattering'' \cite{Kessler:1969, Kessler:1985, Schonhense:1980}.
In particular, the spin polarization is in the direction of $\hat{\textbf{n}}$, the scattering plane defined by the light electric field and electron momentum \cite{Kessler:1985, SOM}. The magnitude is related to the atomic levels considered and to two dynamical parameters that are a function of the ratio $r$ of the radial part of the matrix elements of the two transitions $T_{1,2}$ and of their phase-shift $\phi$ (for details see \cite{Huang:1980, Heinzmann:1980II, Kessler:1985, Cherepkov:1983}).

In photoionization of atoms the kinetic energy $E_k$ of the electron can only be changed by changing the photon energy $h\nu$, thus inevitably changing the matrix elements. The advantage of solid state targets is that it is possible to vary $E_k$ for fixed $h\nu$ by simply looking at different binding energies $E_b$. The drawback, however, is that the dispersion relation necessarily imposes a strict relationship between the measured $E_k$ of the electron and the probed emission angle. This is one of the main difficulties for the development of a general theory treating the spin and phase relationship in photoemission from solids \cite{Irmer:1992}. In addition also other spurious effects related to inelastic scattering and diffraction through the surface have to be taken into account. Our approach, instead of deriving a general new formulation of the problem \textit{ab initio}, consists in adapting the known atomic model to the restrictions of the particular band structure of the solid considered. Since the phase information originates in the local atomic environment it is reasonable to assume a model treating the effects of $\phi$ on the photoelectron properties formally similar to the atomic model \cite{Irmer:1992}.

We consider a photoemission experiment with $\pi$ polarized radiation and fixed $h\nu$ at a $\pi/4$ angle from the detection direction, on a solid system with spin degenerate initial state with $\ell=1$ and $j=1/2$. These choices are dictated by the experiments discussed in the following, but similar expressions can be derived for different experimental setups \cite{Cherepkov:1983}. The component normal to the scattering plane of the measured spin polarization $\textbf{P}$ can be expressed as:

The first term is the spin polarization component of an equivalent atomic photoionization experiment \cite{SOM}, while $\eta$ is a term related to all the spurious effects that might occur in solid state photoemission. These effects can in general cause also the other two components of $\textbf{P}$ to be nonzero.

We now evaluate the derivative with respect to $E_b$ of eq.~\eqref{eq:model} and multiply by $\hbar$. With the definition of $\tau_{\textsc{ews}}$ in eq.~\eqref{eq:EWS} and some algebra, we can write:

We consider a photoemission experiment with $\pi$ polarized radiation and fixed $h\nu$ at a $\pi/4$ angle from the detection direction, on a solid system with spin degenerate initial state with $\ell=1$ and $j=1/2$. These choices are dictated by the experiments discussed in the following, but similar expressions can be derived for different experimental setups \cite{Cherepkov:1983}. The component normal to the scattering plane of the measured spin polarization $\textbf{P}$ can be expressed as:

nexttext:
where the rational functions $f$ and $g$ are reported in ref.\cite{SOM}. When considering a given band with well defined symmetry, it is reasonable to assume that the radial part of the matrix elements do not drastically change in a small angle and binding energy window. Also, given the fact that the incident photon energy is a fixed parameter of the measurement, the spurious effects $\eta$ do not vary sensibly with $E_b$. With these two arguments, the last two terms of eq.~\eqref{eq:derivative} can be considered to be negligible. More realistically, there are particular photon energies that are recognizable \textit{a posteriori} for which these arguments are valid.

Considering the first term in eq.~\eqref{eq:derivative}, it can be shown that $|f|$ is of the order of $1$ when the interference occurs ($r\approx 1$), for any $\phi$ except for a small range where the interference is destructive, and in particular that $\min{\!|f|\!}\approx0.72$ \cite{SOM}. It is important to note that the spin polarization itself is the result of the interference process, therefore the detection with SARPES of a change of $\textbf{P}\cdot\hat{\textbf{n}}$ with $E_b$ is a strong sign of favorable experimental conditions. This leads to a direct estimate of a finite inferior limit for the time-delay of photoemission:
prevtext:
The first term is the spin polarization component of an equivalent atomic photoionization experiment \cite{SOM}, while $\eta$ is a term related to all the spurious effects that might occur in solid state photoemission. These effects can in general cause also the other two components of $\textbf{P}$ to be nonzero.

We now evaluate the derivative with respect to $E_b$ of eq.~\eqref{eq:model} and multiply by $\hbar$. With the definition of $\tau_{\textsc{ews}}$ in eq.~\eqref{eq:EWS} and some algebra, we can write:
